pros:
I have been at Sweetser for 10 years, have held many positions: Assistant supervisor, Shift lead, Floor staff, Overnight Supervisor, Supervisor on Duty, Building Supervisor.

I can say without a doubt that you will never work in a more flexible environment!  I have only been a supervisor for the last year and prior years were spent working directly on the floor with the kids and staff members.   This job is not for everyone, there are weeks, sometimes months where we have very difficult clientele and you begin to wonder if the madness will ever end.  rest assured it does.....I have spent many summers at Sweetser hiking, spending the day at the beach, going to the movies, and bowling.   This job is very rewarding, and can be a ton of fun if you have the right attitude and the willingness and ability to listen more than you need to speak.
cons:
This job is difficult, especially if you are the type of person that needs to have the last word.   this job can be physically demanding.  you will be hit, bit, spit at and called every name in the book.

If your social skills are lousy, and have little desire to learn how to change do not apply.   These kids need an open non judgmental ear.

pros:
I enjoy the teamwork that you can see on the campus! From upper leadership to floor staff.  Everyone works together for the clients best interest. Everyone from supervisors, yfcs to relief staff all work the floor with these clients. Every level of staffing are easy  to communicate to and most have an open door policy to come in and share your thoughts and concerns without feeling like you are in the wrong. 
Its a great job to have if you enjoy working with kids that are troubled and understand that sometimes no matter how hard you try they are not ready for your help and support.
There is a lot of training available either through live trainings or training online. You can sign up for all sorts of training other than the yearly trainings that are required. 
The environment  is laid back and friendly , yet professional.
cons:
Sometimes the hours are long,  the clients don't want the help  or they are not ready for the support. 
It is most definate that there will be times that the clients are aggressive, rude and a lot of the times assaultive.

pros: Co-workers support each other regarding the problems with management, but there is nothing to be done, so quality workers soon leave.
cons: From HR to upper management/executives, I experienced unethical and unprofessional standards from Sweetser. This is an organization that is all about management protecting and putting themselves first. There is a zombie like feeling as staff seems to have to call management "Leadership" -- a very "Big Brother" feel and very hierarchal. Having worked in the field for many years, I can truly say that other non-profits are not this way, and it's very sad that Sweetser, such a large non-profit agency representing Maine social services, should be setting such a poor example. Indeed, employees can get another job, but it is the many hard-working communities throughout Maine that end up losing significantly. Due to overworked, overstressed, underpaid and under-appreciated employees, it is not surprising that the same positions are being filled several times a year because workers are continually leaving.  Sweetser methodologies truly feel  stunted and with an unexpressive and unemotional management , it misrepresents what community services are and are supposed to be. Separate from that, you should know almost everyone complains about the paperwork overload and you will be on a computer easily 6 hours a day, in addition to being in the field 6-8 hours (yes, that means a 12+ hour day). Unfortunately, for no overtime, extremely low pay, and compensation that really doesn't count (I had health insurance but I couldn't afford to use it due to the exorbitant deductible and co-insurance costs), it becomes exhausting and frustrating to work as morale amongst most workers is diminished. Ok, the last but most significant thing to say about working at Sweetser, is that you WILL BE WORKING WITH EXTREMELY VIOLENT AND DANGEROUS CLIENTS ---  so truly beware for your own safety!! After having spoken to many co-workers, it is clear to me that employees are put on the "front lines", not given enough support from management, and not protected with enough training. So, from one professional to another, please, if you work for this agency, go into it with your eyes wide open, refuse to be put in danger's way and demand training, so that you don't become one of many casualties. Everything said, my advice is to run as fast as you can away from Sweetser.
